title: Modifying plots
code: p +   labs(title = 'My comments on the results',        subtitle = NULL,        caption = 'December 2021',        x = 'Mean diff b/t treatment and control')

title: Modifying plots
code: p +    theme_classic() # set the theme for all plots within this R session theme_set(theme_bw())

what: Extract data to reconstruct the plot:
title: Modifying plots

title: Authors and Citation
text: Marlo J, Perrett G (2023). plotBart: Diagnostic Plotting Functions Supplement 'bartCause'. https://priism-center.github.io/plotBart/, https://github.com/priism-center/plotBart.
code: @Manual{,   title = {plotBart: Diagnostic and Plotting Functions to Supplement 'bartCause'},   author = {Joseph Marlo and George Perrett},   year = {2023},   note = {https://priism-center.github.io/plotBart/, https://github.com/priism-center/plotBart}, }

what: Diagnostic and Plotting Functions to Supplement bartCause
title: Diagnostic and Plotting Functions to Supplement bartCause
text: plotBart diagnostic plotting package bartCause thinkCausal.
code: library(plotBart) data(lalonde) confounders <- c('age', 'educ', 'black', 'hisp', 'married', 'nodegr')  # fit BART model model_results <- bartCause::bartc(   response = lalonde[['re78']],   treatment = lalonde[['treat']],   confounders = as.matrix(lalonde[, confounders]),   estimand = 'ate',   commonSup.rule = 'none',   verbose = FALSE,   keepTrees = TRUE )  # plot common support plot_common_support(.model = model_results) # plot CATE and manipulate ggplot object plot_CATE(   .model = model_results,    type = 'density',    ci_80 = TRUE,    ci_95 = TRUE,   .mean = TRUE ) +    labs(subtitle = 'My comments on the results') +   theme_classic()

title: Diagnostic and Plotting Functions to Supplement bartCause
text: plotBart currently development available test installing via:
code: # latest release on CRAN install.packages('plotBart')  # latest development version # install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github('priism-center/plotBart)

what: Plot the histogram or density of the Conditional Average Treatment Effect — plot_CATE
title: Plot the histogram or density of the Conditional Average Treatment Effect — plot_CATE
text: Plot conditional average treatment effect (CATE) 'bartCause' model. conditional average treatment effect derived taking difference predictions individual control condition treatment condition averaged population. Means CATE distribution resemble SATE PATE CATE distribution accounts uncertainty SATE less uncertainty PATE.

title: Plot the histogram or density of the Conditional Average Treatment Effect — plot_CATE
code: plot_CATE(   .model,   type = c("histogram", "density"),   ci_80 = FALSE,   ci_95 = FALSE,   reference = NULL,   .mean = FALSE,   .median = FALSE )

title: Plot the histogram or density of the Conditional Average Treatment Effect — plot_CATE
text: .model model produced `bartCause::bartc()` type histogram density ci_80 TRUE/FALSE. Show 80% credible interval? ci_95 TRUE/FALSE. Show 95% credible interval? reference numeric. Show vertical reference line value .mean TRUE/FALSE. Show mean reference line .median TRUE/FALSE. Show median reference line

title: Plot the histogram or density of the Conditional Average Treatment Effect — plot_CATE

code: # \donttest{ data(lalonde) confounders <- c('age', 'educ', 'black', 'hisp', 'married', 'nodegr') model_results <- bartCause::bartc(  response = lalonde[['re78']],  treatment = lalonde[['treat']],  confounders = as.matrix(lalonde[, confounders]),  estimand = 'ate',  commonSup.rule = 'none' ) #> fitting treatment model via method 'bart' #> fitting response model via method 'bart' plot_CATE(model_results) #> Warning: Ignoring unknown parameters: `ccolour` #> `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.  # }

what: Plot Individual Conditional Average Treatment effects — plot_ICATE
title: Plot Individual Conditional Average Treatment effects — plot_ICATE
text: Plots histogram Individual Conditional Average Treatment effects (ICATE). ICATEs difference individual's predicted outcome treatment predicted outcome control averaged individual. Plots ICATEs useful identify potential heterogeneous treatment effects different individuals. ICATE plots can grouped discrete variables.

title: Plot Individual Conditional Average Treatment effects — plot_ICATE
code: plot_ICATE(.model, .group_by = NULL, n_bins = 30, .alpha = 0.7)

title: Plot Individual Conditional Average Treatment effects — plot_ICATE
text: .model model produced `bartCause::bartc()` .group_by grouping variable vector n_bins number bins .alpha transparency histograms

what: Plot histogram or density of Sample Average Treatment Effects — plot_SATE
title: Plot histogram or density of Sample Average Treatment Effects — plot_SATE
text: Plot histogram density Sample Average Treatment Effect (SATE). Sample Average Treatment Effect derived taking difference individual's observed outcome predicted counterfactual outcome BART model averaged population. mean SATE resemble means CATE PATE account least uncertainty.

title: Plot histogram or density of Sample Average Treatment Effects — plot_SATE
code: plot_SATE(   .model,   type = c("histogram", "density"),   ci_80 = FALSE,   ci_95 = FALSE,   reference = NULL,   .mean = FALSE,   .median = FALSE,   check_overlap = FALSE,   overlap_rule = c("none", "sd", "chisq") )

title: Plot histogram or density of Sample Average Treatment Effects — plot_SATE
text: .model model produced `bartCause::bartc()` type histogram density ci_80 TRUE/FALSE. Show 80% credible interval? ci_95 TRUE/FALSE. Show 95% credible interval? reference numeric. Show vertical reference line x-axis value .mean TRUE/FALSE. Show mean reference line .median TRUE/FALSE. Show median reference line check_overlap TRUE/FALSE. Check overlap rules applicable overlap_rule enter overlap rules view different bartCause removal rules influenced results. applicable check_overlap TRUE.

title: Plot histogram or density of Sample Average Treatment Effects — plot_SATE

title: Plot the balance — plot_balance
text: Visualize balance variables treatment control groups. Balance plot reflects balance standardized units.

title: Plot the balance — plot_balance
code: plot_balance(   .data,   treatment,   confounders,   compare = c("means", "variance", "covariance"),   estimand = c("ATE", "ATT", "ATC") )

title: Plot the balance — plot_balance
text: .data dataframe treatment column denoted treatment. Must binary. confounders character list column names denoting X columns interest compare character either means variance denotes compare balance estimand character either ATE, ATT ATC causal estimand making inferences

title: Plot the balance — plot_balance
Plot the balance — plot_balance
Plot the balance — plot_balance
code: data(lalonde) plot_balance(lalonde, 'treat', c('re78', 'age', 'educ'), compare = 'means', estimand = 'ATE') + labs(title = 'My new title')

what: Plot common support based on the standard deviation rule, chi squared rule, or both — plot_common_support
title: Plot common support based on the standard deviation rule, chi squared rule, or both — plot_common_support
text: Plot common support based standard deviation rule, chi squared rule, .

title: Plot common support based on the standard deviation rule, chi squared rule, or both — plot_common_support
code: plot_common_support(   .model,   .x = "Propensity Score",   .y = "stat",   rule = c("both", "sd", "chi") )

title: Plot common support based on the standard deviation rule, chi squared rule, or both — plot_common_support
text: .model model produced `bartCause::bartc()` .x character string denoting covariate use x axis default propensity score .y character string denoting covariate use y axis default common support statistic rule one c('', 'sd', 'chi') denoting rule use identify lack support

title: Plot common support based on the standard deviation rule, chi squared rule, or both — plot_common_support
Plot common support based on the standard deviation rule, chi squared rule, or both — plot_common_support
text: Sufficient overlap/common support assumption causal inference. BART models use uncertainty counter factual uncertainty. posterior distribution individual's counterfactual prediction extends beyond specified cut-point, point likely insufficient common support. 'bartCause' model offer option automatically remove points without common support analyses, however, must specified model fitting. Cut-points determined one two rules: standard deviation (sd) chi-squared (chi). standard deviation rule, point weak common support posterior distribution counterfactual deviation greater maximum posterior observed predictions 1 standard deviation distribution standard deviations individual's predicted outcome observed assignment. chi-squared rule, point discarded variance counterfactual prediction observed prediction statistically different chi-squared distribution 1 degree freedom. details discard rules see Hill Su 2013. called plot show many points removed standard deviation chi-squared rules. plot used diagnostic 'bartCause' models fit without common-support rule.

title: Plot common support based on the standard deviation rule, chi squared rule, or both — plot_common_support
text: Hill, J., & Su, Y. S. (2013). Assessing lack common support causal inference using Bayesian nonparametrics: Implications evaluating effect breastfeeding children's cognitive outcomes. Annals Applied Statistics, 1386-1420.

title: Plot common support based on the standard deviation rule, chi squared rule, or both — plot_common_support
Plot common support based on the standard deviation rule, chi squared rule, or both — plot_common_support
code: # \donttest{ data(lalonde) confounders <- c('age', 'educ', 'black', 'hisp', 'married', 'nodegr') model_results <- bartCause::bartc(  response = lalonde[['re78']],  treatment = lalonde[['treat']],  confounders = as.matrix(lalonde[, confounders]),  estimand = 'ate',  commonSuprule = 'none' ) #> fitting treatment model via method 'bart' #> fitting response model via method 'bart' plot_common_support(model_results)  plot_common_support(model_results, .x = 'age')  # }

title: Plot the covariance — plot_covariance
text: Visualize balance covariance variables treatment control groups. Balance plot reflects balance standardized units.

title: Plot the covariance — plot_covariance
code: plot_covariance(.data, treatment, confounders)

title: Plot the covariance — plot_covariance
text: .data dataframe treatment column denoted treatment. Must binary. confounders character list column names denoting X columns interest

what: Auto-Bin a plot of a continuous moderating variable into a discrete moderating variable — plot_moderator_c_bin
title: Auto-Bin a plot of a continuous moderating variable into a discrete moderating variable — plot_moderator_c_bin
text: Use regression tree optimally bin continous variable

title: Auto-Bin a plot of a continuous moderating variable into a discrete moderating variable — plot_moderator_c_bin
code: plot_moderator_c_bin(   .model,   moderator,   type = c("density", "histogram", "errorbar"),   .alpha = 0.7,   facet = FALSE,   .ncol = 1,   .name = "bin" )

title: Auto-Bin a plot of a continuous moderating variable into a discrete moderating variable — plot_moderator_c_bin
text: .model model produced `bartCause::bartc()` moderator moderator vector type string specify like plot histogram, density error bar plot .alpha transparency value [0, 1] facet TRUE/FALSE. Create panel plots moderator level? .ncol number columns use faceting .name sting representing name moderating variable

title: Auto-Bin a plot of a continuous moderating variable into a discrete moderating variable — plot_moderator_c_bin
Auto-Bin a plot of a continuous moderating variable into a discrete moderating variable — plot_moderator_c_bin

code: # \donttest{ data(lalonde) confounders <- c('age', 'educ', 'black', 'hisp', 'married', 'nodegr') model_results <- bartCause::bartc(  response = lalonde[['re78']],  treatment = lalonde[['treat']],  confounders = as.matrix(lalonde[, confounders]),  estimand = 'ate',  commonSuprule = 'none' ) #> fitting treatment model via method 'bart' #> fitting response model via method 'bart' plot_moderator_c_bin(model_results, lalonde$age, .name = 'age') #> Joining with `by = join_by(splits)`  # }

text: .model model produced `bartCause::bartc()` moderator moderator vector n_bins number bins cut moderator . Defaults lesser 15 number distinct levels moderator

text: Green, D. P., & Kern, H. L. (2012). Modeling heterogeneous treatment effects survey experiments Bayesian additive regression trees. Public opinion quarterly, 76(3), 491-511.

what: Plot a single regression tree of covariates on ICATEs — plot_moderator_search
title: Plot a single regression tree of covariates on ICATEs — plot_moderator_search
text: Plot single regression tree exploratory heterogeneous effects. Fit single regression tree bartc() ICATEs produce variable importance plot. plot useful identifying potential moderating variables. Tree depth may set depths 1, 2 3. Terminal nodes signal Conditional Average Treatment effect within levels moderation variables. Trees different values across terminal nodes suggest strong treatment effect moderation.

title: Plot a single regression tree of covariates on ICATEs — plot_moderator_search
code: plot_moderator_search(.model, max_depth = c(2, 1, 3))

title: Plot a single regression tree of covariates on ICATEs — plot_moderator_search
text: .model model produced `bartCause::bartc()` max_depth one c(1, 2, 3). Maximum number node levels within tree. 2 recommended

title: Plot a single regression tree of covariates on ICATEs — plot_moderator_search
Plot a single regression tree of covariates on ICATEs — plot_moderator_search

title: Plot the overlap via propensity score method — plot_overlap_pScores
text: .data dataframe treatment character. Name treatment column within .data confounders character list column names denoting confounders within .data plot_type plot type, one c('Histogram', 'Density') min_x numeric value specifying minimum propensity score value shown x axis max_x numeric value specifying maximum propensity score value shown x axis pscores propensity scores. provided, propensity scores calculated using BART ... additional arguments passed `dbarts::bart2` propensity score calculation

title: Plot the overlap via propensity score method — plot_overlap_pScores

code: # \donttest{ data(lalonde) plot_overlap_pScores(  .data = lalonde,  treatment = 'treat',  confounders = c('age', 'educ'),  plot_type = 'histogram',  pscores = NULL,  seed = 44 ) #>  #> Running BART with binary y #>  #> number of trees: 75 #> number of chains: 4, number of threads 2 #> tree thinning rate: 1 #> Prior: #> 	prior on k: chi with 1.250000 degrees of freedom and inf scale #> 	power and base for tree prior: 2.000000 0.950000 #> 	use quantiles for rule cut points: false #> 	proposal probabilities: birth/death 0.50, swap 0.10, change 0.40; birth 0.50 #> data: #> 	number of training observations: 445 #> 	number of test observations: 0 #> 	number of explanatory variables: 2 #>  #> Cutoff rules c in x<=c vs x>c #> Number of cutoffs: (var: number of possible c): #> (1: 100) (2: 100)  #> Running mcmc loop: #> [1] iteration: 100 (of 500) #> [2] iteration: 100 (of 500) #> [2] iteration: 200 (of 500) #> [1] iteration: 200 (of 500) #> [1] iteration: 300 (of 500) #> [2] iteration: 300 (of 500) #> [1] iteration: 400 (of 500) #> [2] iteration: 400 (of 500) #> [1] iteration: 500 (of 500) #> [2] iteration: 500 (of 500) #> [3] iteration: 100 (of 500) #> [4] iteration: 100 (of 500) #> [3] iteration: 200 (of 500) #> [4] iteration: 200 (of 500) #> [3] iteration: 300 (of 500) #> [4] iteration: 300 (of 500) #> [3] iteration: 400 (of 500) #> [4] iteration: 400 (of 500) #> [3] iteration: 500 (of 500) #> [4] iteration: 500 (of 500) #> total seconds in loop: 0.673978 #>  #> Tree sizes, last iteration: #> [1] 3 5 2 3 4 3 2 1 2 2 2 3 2 2 2 2 2 2  #> 2 2 3 4 3 3 3 2 2 2 1 3 what: Plot the overlap of variables — plot_overlap_vars
title: Plot the overlap of variables — plot_overlap_vars
text: Plot histograms showing overlap variables treatment status.

title: Plot the overlap of variables — plot_overlap_vars
code: plot_overlap_vars(   .data,   treatment,   confounders,   plot_type = c("histogram", "density"),   min_x = NULL,   max_x = NULL )

title: Plot the overlap of variables — plot_overlap_vars
text: .data dataframe treatment character. Name treatment column within .data confounders character list column names denoting confounders within .data plot_type plot type, one c('histogram', 'density'). Defaults 'histogram' min_x numeric value specifying minimum value shown x axis max_x numeric value specifying maximum value shown x axis

title: Plot the overlap of variables — plot_overlap_vars
Plot the overlap of variables — plot_overlap_vars
Plot the overlap of variables — plot_overlap_vars
code: data(lalonde) plot_overlap_vars(  .data = lalonde,  treatment = 'treat',  confounders = c('age', 'educ'),  plot_type = 'Histogram' ) #> `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`. #> `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.

title: Plot the model residual — plot_residual_density
text: Visualize balance variables treatment control groups. Balance plot reflects balance standardized units.

title: Plot the model residual — plot_residual_density
code: plot_residual_density(.model)

title: Plot the model residual — plot_residual_density
Plot the model residual — plot_residual_density
Plot the model residual — plot_residual_density
Plot the model residual — plot_residual_density
code: # \donttest{ data(lalonde) confounders <- c('age', 'educ', 'black', 'hisp', 'married', 'nodegr') model_results <- bartCause::bartc(  response = lalonde[['re78']],  treatment = lalonde[['treat']],  confounders = as.matrix(lalonde[, confounders]),  estimand = 'ate',  commonSup.rule = 'none' ) #> fitting treatment model via method 'bart' #> fitting response model via method 'bart' plot_residual_density(model_results)  # }

what: Trace plot the estimands of a `bartCause::bartc()` model — plot_trace
title: Trace plot the estimands of a `bartCause::bartc()` model — plot_trace
text: Returns ggplot estimated effect iteration model fit. used visually assess convergence Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) sampling. Chains well mixed single color notably separate others.

title: Trace plot the estimands of a `bartCause::bartc()` model — plot_trace
code: plot_trace(.model)

title: Trace plot the estimands of a `bartCause::bartc()` model — plot_trace
Trace plot the estimands of a `bartCause::bartc()` model — plot_trace
Trace plot the estimands of a `bartCause::bartc()` model — plot_trace
Trace plot the estimands of a `bartCause::bartc()` model — plot_trace
code: # \donttest{ data(lalonde) confounders <- c('age', 'educ', 'black', 'hisp', 'married', 'nodegr') model_results <- bartCause::bartc(  response = lalonde[['re78']],  treatment = lalonde[['treat']],  confounders = as.matrix(lalonde[, confounders]),  estimand = 'ate',  commonSup.rule = 'none' ) #> fitting treatment model via method 'bart' #> fitting response model via method 'bart' plot_trace(.model = model_results)  # }

what: Plot a waterfall of the ICATEs — plot_waterfall
title: Plot a waterfall of the ICATEs — plot_waterfall
text: Plots point posterior intervals individual's ICATE ordered ICATE continuous variable. Points can colored discrete variable. Waterfall plots useful visual diagnostic possible treatment effect heterogeneity. flat line implies little treatment effect heterogeneity steeper curve implies treatment effect varies across individuals sample. Ordering points continuous variable coloring points discrete variable can helpful identify potential moderators treatment effect.

title: Plot a waterfall of the ICATEs — plot_waterfall
code: plot_waterfall(   .model,   descending = TRUE,   .order = NULL,   .color = NULL,   .alpha = 0.5 )

title: Plot a waterfall of the ICATEs — plot_waterfall
text: .model model produced `bartCause::bartc()` descending order ICATEs value? .order vector representing custom order .color vector representing colors .alpha transparency value [0, 1]

title: Plot a waterfall of the ICATEs — plot_waterfall
Plot a waterfall of the ICATEs — plot_waterfall
Plot a waterfall of the ICATEs — plot_waterfall
code: # \donttest{ data(lalonde) confounders <- c('age', 'educ', 'black', 'hisp', 'married', 'nodegr') model_results <- bartCause::bartc(  response = lalonde[['re78']],  treatment = lalonde[['treat']],  confounders = as.matrix(lalonde[, confounders]),  estimand = 'ate',  commonSuprule = 'none' ) #> fitting treatment model via method 'bart' #> fitting response model via method 'bart' plot_waterfall(model_results)  # }

title: Print balance statistics — print_balance
text: See balance statisitics variables treatment control groups.

title: Print balance statistics — print_balance
code: print_balance(.data, treatment, confounders, estimand = c("ATE", "ATT", "ATC"))

title: Print balance statistics — print_balance
text: .data dataframe treatment column denoted treatment. Must binary. confounders character list column names denoting X columns interest estimand character either ATE, ATT ATC causal estimand making inferences

title: Print balance statistics — print_balance
Print balance statistics — print_balance
Print balance statistics — print_balance
code: data(lalonde) print_balance(lalonde, 'treat', confounders = c('re78', 'age', 'educ'), estimand = 'ATE') #> # A tibble: 3 × 4 #>   variable `difference in means` `standardized difference in means` ratio of t…¹ #>   <chr>                    <dbl> <chr>                              <chr>        #> 1 age                       0.76 0.11                               1.01         #> 2 educ                      0.26 0.14                               1.25         #> 3 re78                   1794.   0.26                               1.43         #> # … with abbreviated variable name ¹​`ratio of the variance`

title: Print covariance statistics — print_covariance
text: See balance statistics covariance specified variables treatment control groups.

title: Print covariance statistics — print_covariance
code: print_covariance(   .data,   treatment,   confounders,   estimand = c("ATE", "ATT", "ATC") )

title: Print covariance statistics — print_covariance
text: .data dataframe treatment column denoted treatment. Must binary. confounders character list column names denoting X columns interest estimand character either ATE, ATT ATC causal estimand making inferences

title: Print covariance statistics — print_covariance
Print covariance statistics — print_covariance
Print covariance statistics — print_covariance
code: data(lalonde) print_covariance(lalonde, 'treat', confounders = c('re78', 'age', 'educ'), estimand = 'ATE') #> # A tibble: 3 × 2 #>   variable  `standardized difference in means` #>   <chr>                                  <dbl> #> 1 re78*educ                               0.29 #> 2 re78*age                                0.29 #> 3 age*educ                                0.16
